Baghdad
Sep
September
4 Received
11 Oct 1921
1921
Darling Father. The Post, having exerted itself unconscionably last
week, has rested on its laurels + I have no further letters from you.
Nor has it been a week of so much incident in other respects -
we've crown d ed no more kings. It has been entirely occupied with
subterranean agitation over the forming of the new Cabinet. I told you
that Ja'far had unbosomed himself to me on the balcony of Faisal's
house; I was next to receive the confidences of Faisal himself.
He sent for me on Wednesday + I went at tea time. I hadn't been
there a minute when Major Yetts was announced. We agreed to have
him in + we had a most successful three
cornered cornerd
talk.
For the Dulaim is one of our best divisions. It's cultivation
has enormously increased + its yield in taxation gone up
three fold in the last four years; but Major Yetts doesn't blow
his own trumpet + I like a sort of Mrs Markham was
useful in putting leading questions, such as, "Tell us dear
Major Yetts how your present returns compare with those of
1918?" Faisal was delighted + encouraged with his
account - or should I say accounts? - + they
passed on to a discussion on desert tribes in which
they were in complete agreement. The problem is that the
Shammar Arab tribe descended from the Yemeni tribe of Tayy. , harried by Ibn Sa'ud, have fled in large numbers
from the vicinity of Hail + taken refuge with our own 'Anizah.
From that safe retreat they design to harry Ibn Sa'ud's
tribes in turn, but Fahad Beg rightly says that he
will come off second best for his tribes will share
in the counter raids which Ibn Sa'ud will certainly
hurt against the Shammar. Faisal was most wise about
it + concocted schemes for restraining the Shammar,
even though he ardently desires (+ so do we all) to see,
Ibn Sa'ud frustrated in his attempt to capture Hail.
After Major Yetts had gone Faisal talked to me very
earnestly about the Cabinet. The crux is the Interior
which has been vacant ever since Talib was bundled out.

If Mr Hogarth asks you for my Faisal letters please send them
unexpurgated.

Faisal says quite correctly, that the first appointments are of
extreme importance to him because he will be judged by them.
If he puts in figure heads just because they are known to
be safe men + loyal to us, all the ardent people who want
to be up + doing (+ after all they are the only people who
are any good) will say the new Cabinet is a farce + Faisal
himself not a king but a puppet of the English "+ that
won't be either to you or to me at all profitable". On the
other hand since this Cabinet has to watch over
the summoning of the Congress + the drawing up of the
Organic Law it's of the first moment that it
should be staunch + steady, not lose its head
when a parcel of young idiots pass remarks in
coffee shops. The obvious person for the Interior is
Naji Suwaidi, but though he is clever + well meaning
he just isn't steady + I thought at first that Sir Percy
was right in saying that he would not have him. The
superlative difficulty of finding any substitute but a
figure head has brought me to a different opinion.
We should never be able to close an eye if Naji were in
the Interior, but with constant watching I think we could
make him run straight. I told Faisal this but added
that I was a servant of Sir Percy + could hold
no opinion apart from his. However if Mr Cornwallis
was of the same view I would see Sir Percy in the
morning + try to move him on the subject of Naji.
With that - it being then time for Faisal's prayers -
I went round to Mr Cornwallis + found that he agreed
entirely. But Sir Percy wasn't to be moved - I won't
put my judgment against his; in the end I usually
if not always find that he was right, + I told him as
much. Finally they've hit on a man. He is a certain
Taufiq Khalidi, an ex- deputy + a clever, well educated

2 person, speaking French + German excellently. The trouble
about him is that he is generally reputed to be pro-
Turkish + he will never have the complete confidence
of Faisal. I think myself that he is too intelligent + too
well informed on politics to believe either that the Turks
will ever come back here or that it would be an
advantage that they should, but like all the best men
he has a Turkish training + he will lean to Turkish
ways. I personally like him very much + I'm quite prepared
to find that as usual Sir Percy has turned out to be
right, only the people I love next best to him,
Faisal, Ja'far etc, aren't happy. There is a very wide
feeling that Taufiq is too pro-Turkish; I heard it
pretty strongly expressed from by Haji Naji this
morning - the appointment isn't announced yet
but there has been gossip about Taufiq. I told Haji
Naji to hitch his wagon to Sir Percy + he agreed that
with this procedure nothing could go wrong.
At least no one can say that Taufig isn't a
capable man with general qualifications for the job.
Naji becomes Minister of Justice.
It does take a great deal of watching. I saw in the Arab
press the other day that one of the worst of scalliwags
had been appointed Treasurer to Faisal's household.
I've known the gentleman, namens Taha Lutfi, since
March 1916 + I've never known him not to be a
mischief maker while often he has been a great
deal worse. I telephoned to Mr Cornwallis - he
knew nothing + on enquiry Faisal knew nothing
special - he had just been told that Taha Lutfi's
character closely resembled that of
Mr Terrapin Refers to a children's fable. . So
I drew up a long dossier + we are now all

trying to get
Mr Terrapin Refers to a children's fable.
out again. From the point of
view of the Taha Lutfis I must be a terrible
recording devil, for I've sat uninterruptedly in the
middle of the web + all the flies, mosquitoes, + gnats
- even the midges - are familiar to me.
To return to pro-Turks: there's an intensive propaganda
going on + that pole with a sheet draped over it, Ahmad
Sanusi, is sending down quantities of letters urging
tribes + individuals to rise against us + Faisal in
the name of Islam. I think it's almost
negligible negligable , but it just isn't quite. If we could catch
a few of these messengers - but we've never succeeded
in doing so yet though many of the letters have come
into our hands. Ja'far is a little agitated. He
came in late one evening with authentic information
of two Turkish officers who were in Mandali. With
Sir Percy's permission I telegraphed next morning to
the Advisor, Ba'qubah, + asked him to pay a
casual visit to Mandali. A man I know very well,
Rauf Chadirji, tumbled into the office that day
saying that an unknown individual had just called
on him on behalf of Nihad Pasha, the Turkish
C. C. Chief Commander
on our front!
- As I reached this point, Ja'far rolled up to explain
to me that the appointment of Taufiq would be fatal
because all the Turkish party would sit up + prick their
ears + he felt certain that under these conditions he
couldn't get recruits. He had told Faisal he would resign.
I jumped on him for that + said he had got to serve through
thick + thin like the rest of us. Well, then, would I come + see
Faisal who was in despair + was talking of going to
England to lay the matter before the
S. of S. Secretary of State
So with that I
got into Jafar's car + went off to Faisal where to

3 my joy I found Mr Cornwallis. Colonel Joyce also came
in + we unitedly told Faisal he mustn't go to England
now, because the whole country would say he had
quarrelled with Sir Percy over the Cabinet + it would
be fatal for both of them. I think we persuaded him
but we got no further with the Cabinet. Ja'far is to see
Sir Percy this evening + Faisal tomorrow morning + what will
come of it I don't know.
They are no less out against the French than the Turks + I
can't really wonder. Sir Percy has caught out the French
consul here in a deliberate lie of a very malicious kind
- it's all in black + white. He declared he didn't make the
statement + Gouraud then incautiously said he had had the following
telegram from him ... As a result Sir Percy wont have any
more personal intercourse with the Consul, Chaubet, + I
think he'll be withdrawn. But we shall have another as
bad whom we shall have to catch out in turn. Added
to this comes authentic news from the north that the
French
Govt Government
in Syria have sent £20,000 to the Sanusi
to help him in his propaganda against Faisal +
ourselves - pretty, isn't it! They are impossible people.
This last paragraph is secret + indeed so is all
the Cabinet crisis. You are my diary - poor you! -
+ I write down everything as it happens.
I had a dinner party this week for Major Yetts - 'Abdullah
Dulaimi, who is one of the very best of the younger men, I think,
he is an officer recently returned from Syria; Hamdi Pachahji, a
clever, unstable Baghdadi; Rustam Haidar of Faisal's household;
Nuri Pasha
CGS Chief of the General Staff , + 'Ali Jaudat an officer recently returned
- I am rather uncertain about him, he is clever + well
educated but he's doing all he knows to be appointed
Mutasarrif Governor of an administrative district.
of Mosul + he certainly isn't fit for the job. It was a nice party.

The
Cunliffe Owens Mr Frederick Cunliffe Owen and his Wife, Marguerite Cunliffe Owen.
are here, on their way home. His job is finally
over, the Assyrians having all been dispersed. Some have
settled in Mosul wilayat, others have wandered up to Russia,
been turned back, + are how existing aimlessly in Mesopotamia,
but not at our expense. The
C.O Cunliffe Owen s came to tea with me
yesterday + I met them at a little party which
Coxes Sir Percy Cox and his Wife, Lady Louisa Belle Cox.
gave last night in their garden - 9 to 12. It was extremely
pretty, sofas + carpets on the lawn, + the bushes + palm
trees hung with lights. It was also very pleasant but it rather
breaks my heart that Lady Cox does nothing for the young
men of our service - they are never invited to the house. She
spends her whole time with the Air Force. Our people come
in from the provinces where they have been doing the harvest,
solitary work, + no notice is taken of them. Similarly, except
for a chosen one or two she sees none of the men in the
offices here. It is such a pity.
Last night was the first of
Muharram The first month of the Islamic calendar. . On the 10th
Husain was killed in the battle of Karbala. The lanterns
in the Coxes' garden were outshone by the flaming torches
of the processions outside, which with cries + beatings of
breasts paraded the streets, mourning for Husain.
The weather is unspeakable. These September days when
the summer burns itself out are the worst in the
year + absolutely still, the white mist hangs heavy over the
river at morning + evening. And you feel like a rag of the
worst quality. I pulled myself together + rode out to
Haji Naji before breakfast - at least I actually
breakfasted there on bread + fruit + sour milk. I
hadn't had the energy to go so far for more than
a month. This evening I went swimming with the young men
in the office. It was supremely delicious, the water like oil
+ a tiny moon setting above us. Opposite where we bathe, Faisal
was standing on the balcony of his new house watching us dive
from the buoy in mid stream. Your devoted daughter
Gertrude

On His Majesty's Service.
